facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1955 filed under Article 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1955. Appeal under Article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal against High Court order dated November 24, 1954 in Original Petition No. 53 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: of India from the Judgment and Order dated November 24, 1954, of the former Travancore-Cochin High Court in Original Petition No. 53 of 1954. N. Subramania Iyer and R. Ganapathy Iyer, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed Original Petition No. 53 of 1954 filed by appellant under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against the order of the High Court of Travancore-Cochin dismissing the Original Petition No. 53 of 1954 filed by the appellant under Art. 226 for quashing the order of the Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon,

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon assessed appellant to sales tax on net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 for year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the order of the Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon, assessing him to sales tax on a net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 for the year 1951-52  1st April, 1951 to 31st March, 1952  and for issuing proper directions

facts.text: Appellant is a registered manufacturer of coconut oil and cake with certificate in Form VI per sub-r. (i) of r. 20 of Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: to the Sales Tax Authorities to assess the same according to law. The appellant is a registered manufacturer of companyoanut oil and cake who has obtained a certificate of registration in Form VI as per sub-r.  i  of r. 20 of the Travancore- Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant's business: purchase of copra, manufacture of coconut oil and cake, sale inside and outside Travancore-Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the appellant for the purposes of this appeal companysisted in the purchase of companyra, manufacture of companyoanut oil and cake and sale of the same to parties inside the State of Travancore- Cochin and sale of the oil to parties outside the State.

facts.text: In 1951-52, appellant purchased copra value Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1951-52, the appellant purchased companyra of the value of Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 and after manufacturing oil therefrom in his oil mills he sold the oil partly in the State and partly outside the State and the cake entirely within the State.,

facts.text: Total value of oil sold Rs. 6,76,719-0-11, of which sales outside State Rs. 3,67,816-10-1.

anchor.surface_text: The total value of the oil sold was Rs. 6,76,719-0-11 out of which the sales outside the State were of the value of Rs. 3,67,816-10-1 and the value of the cake sold in the State was Rs. 67,155-155.

facts.text: Value of cake sold in State Rs. 67,155-15-5.

anchor.surface_text: the value of the cake sold in the State was Rs. 67,155-155. The total gross turnover of the appellant was thus Rs. 14,59,923-1-8 and he claimed to deduct therefrom the whole of the purchase price of the companyra under r. 7  1   k  read with r. 20.

facts.text: Total gross turnover Rs. 14,59,923-1-8.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 67,155-155. The total gross turnover of the appellant was thus Rs. 14,59,923-1-8 and he claimed to deduct therefrom the whole of the purchase price of the companyra under r. 7  1   k  read with r. 20. The net turnover according to him was therefore only Rs. 7,43,875-0-4

facts.text: Appellant claimed net turnover Rs. 7,43,875-0-4 after deducting copra purchase, further deduct Rs. 3,67,816-10-1 for inter-State sales, net assessable Rs. 3,76,058-6-3.

anchor.surface_text: The net turnover according to him was therefore only Rs. 7,43,875-0-4 and he claimed to deduct out of this a further sum of Rs. 3,67,816- 10-1 being the sale price of oil in inter-State transactions which companyld number be taxed under Art. 286 of the Constitution, thus showing a net assessable turnover of only Rs. 3,76 058-6-3.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer fixed net assessable turnover at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 by taking copra Rs. 7,16,048-1-4, adding oil inside Rs. 3,08,902-6-10 and cake Rs. 67,155-15-5, deducting copra for inside oil Rs. 3,35,216-0-0, added gum Rs. 3,385-0-3, deducted tax collected Rs. 6,130-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon, however fixed the net assessable turnover of the appellant at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4. He took the purchase value of the companyra at Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 but added thereto Rs. 3,08,902-6-10 and Rs. 67,155-15-5 being the respective values of the oil and the cake sold inside the State, excluding the sale price of inter-State sales of oil, namely, Rs. 3,67,816-10-1, from such companyputation.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Assistant Sales Tax Commissioner, S.T.A. No. 1480 of 1953-54, dismissed May 10, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus excluded the sale price of inter-State sales of oil, he deducted only the value of the companyra companyresponding to the oil sold inside the State namely, Rs. 3,35,216-0-0, as against the sum of Rs.7,16,048-1-4 deducted by the appellant. He added a sum of Rs. 3,385-0-3 being the price of gum sold by the appellant and deducted a further sum of Rs. 6,130-15-6 being the sales tax companylected by him.

facts.text: Petition to Government dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: He thus arrived at the net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 and assessed the appellant for sales tax on the same. The appellant preferred an appeal to the Assistant Sales Tax Commissioner  S.T.A. No. 1480 of 1953-54  who dismissed the same by his order dated May 10, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant sold gum for Rs. 3,385-0-3.

anchor.surface_text: He added a sum of Rs. 3,385-0-3 being the price of gum sold by the appellant and deducted a further sum of Rs. 6,130-15-6 being the sales tax companylected by him. He thus arrived at the net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 and assessed the appellant for sales tax on the same.

facts.text: Sales tax collected by appellant Rs. 6,130-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: by the appellant and deducted a further sum of Rs. 6,130-15-6 being the sales tax companylected by him. He thus arrived at the net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 and assessed the appellant for sales tax on the same. The appellant preferred an appeal to the Assistant Sales Tax Commissioner

facts.text: Appellant contends entitled to deduct whole copra purchase from gross turnover including for inter-state oil sales.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytroversy between the parties centres on the method of calculation of the net turnover. The appellant companytends that in the calculation of such net turnover he is entitled to include the total value of the oil sold by him, viz., Rs. 6,76,719-0-11, irrespective of the fact whether these sales were effected inside the State or outside the State and deduct therefrom the total value of companyra purchased by him from which the whole quantity of oil sold by him was manufactured, viz., Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

facts.text: Sales Tax Authorities contend inter-state sales and corresponding copra purchase not to be included in turnover calculation due to s.26.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Authorities on the other hand, companytend that the appellant is number entitled to take into companyputation at all his sales of oil outside the State and is also number entitled to deduct from his gross turnover the purchase price of companyra allocated to the oil sold to persons outside the State.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125 received assent of Rajpramukh on January 5, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Act as originally enacted received the assent of the Rajpramukh on January 5, 1950. After the advent of the Constitution, however, the Act was amended by the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax  Amendment  Act, 1951,

facts.text: Act amended by Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1951 adding s.26.

anchor.surface_text: the Act was amended by the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax  Amendment  Act, 1951, and s. 26 was added thereto which ran as under Notwithstanding anything companytained in this Act -  a  a tax on the sale or purchase of goods shall number be imposed under this Act

anchor.surface_text: and s. 26 was added thereto which ran as under Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act -  a  a tax on the sale or purchase of goods shall not be imposed under this Act  i  where such sale or purchase takes place outside the State of Travancore-Cochin or  ii  where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of import of the goods into, or export of the goods out of, the territory of India  b  a tax on the sale or purchase of any goods shall not, after the 31st day of March, 1951, be imposed where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce except in so far as Parliament may by law otherwise provide.

concepts.interpretation: Non-obstante provision obliterates application of Act's taxing provisions to inter-state sales etc., excluding them from turnover calculations entirely.

concepts.unlisted_description: Incorporates Art. 286 restrictions as overriding provision.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2  j  defined a sale as under Sale with all its grammatical variations and cognate expressions means every transfer of the property in goods by one person to another in the course of trade or business for cash or for deferred payment or other valuable consideration Explanation  2  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Sale of Goods Act for the time being in force, the sale or purchase of any goods shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act, to have taken place in the United State wherever the contract of sale or purchase might have been made.

concepts.interpretation: Wide definition includes inter-state sales unless excluded by s.26.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2  k  defined turnover as the aggregate amount for which goods are either bought by or sold by a dealer, whether for cash or for deferred payment or other valuable consideration, provided that the proceeds of the sale by a person of agricultural or horticultural produce grown by himself or grown on any land in which he has an interest whether as owner, usufructuary mortgagee, tenant or otherwise, shall be excluded from his turnover.

concepts.interpretation: Aggregate of buys/sells, no distinction intra/inter-state unless s.26 applies.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: a dealer. Such net turnover is to be arrived at after deducting from the gross turnover various amounts specified in cls.  a  to  k  thereof and cl.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 was the charging section and it provided for levy of taxes on sales of goods in the terms following- Subject to the provisions of this Act a  every dealer shall pay for each year a tax on his total turnover for such year and  b  the tax shall be calculated at the rate of three pies for every Indian rupee in such turnover A dealer whose total turnover in any year is less than ten thousand Indian rupees shall not be liable to pay any tax for that year under sub-section  1  or sub-section  2 .

concepts.interpretation: Tax on total turnover determined per rules; s.26 overrides for certain sales.

issues.text: Which of the two contending methods for calculating the net assessable turnover of a registered coconut oil manufacturer—who sells oil both inside and outside the State—is correct under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act and Rules, given the prohibition on taxing inter-State sales under Section 26?

anchor.surface_text: They claim to lift the whole of these sales of oil outside the State inclusive of the purchase price of the copra which can be allocated to them out of the calculations of the net turnover because of the provisions of s. 26 set out above, relying upon the non-obstante provision contained therein, viz., 'Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, a tax on the sale or purchase of goods shall not be imposed under this Act where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.' We have to decide which of these calculations of the net turnover is correct having regard to the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules made there-under.

issues.text: What is the effect of the non-obstante provision in Section 26 of the Act on the other provisions of the Act and Rules regarding imposition of tax on inter-State sales?

anchor.surface_text: with the result that the Sales Tax Authorities founded themselves upon the non-obstante provision incorporated in the Act by the addition of s. 26 therein by the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1951. issues.text: Is there a distinction between the inclusion of the value of inter-State sales of oil in the dealer's turnover for the purpose of assessment (and claiming deduction under Rule 20) and the levy of tax thereon prohibited by Section 26?

anchor.surface_text: The amount for which the oil is sold in inter-State trade or commerce would not be lawfully included in the turnover of the dealer and no question would arise of the applicability of r. 7 (1) (k) and r. 20 (2) at all to these cases. A distinction was sought to be made between the inclusion of the value of such oil in the turnover of the dealer for the purpose of assessment and the levy of tax thereupon.

issues.text: Is there a broad distinction between statutory provisions regarding exemptions/refunds/rebates of tax (requiring inclusion in turnover then deduction) and provisions regarding non-liability/non-imposition of tax (excluding from turnover altogether)?

anchor.surface_text: There is a broad distinction between the provisions contained in the statute in regard to the exemptions of tax or refund or rebate of tax on the one hand and in regard to the non-liability to tax or non-imposition of tax on the other. In the former case, but for the provisions as regards the exemptions or refund or rebate of tax, the sales or purchases would have to be included in the gross turnover of the dealer because they are prima facie liable to tax

arguments.claim: Three stages of tax imposition: declaration of liability first; no liability under s.26 means no assessment/inclusion in turnover.

anchor.surface_text: As has been pointed out by the Federal Court in Chatturam C.I.T., Bihar , quoting from the judgment of Lord Dunedin in Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue there are three stages in the imposition of a tax. There is the declaration of liability,

arguments.claim: Distinction: exemption/rebate provisions include sales in gross turnover then deduct; no-liability/non-imposition excludes from turnover/purview of Act entirely; s.26 is latter.

holdings.text: Section 26 of the Act, in cases falling within the categories specified under Art. 286 of the Constitution has the effect of setting at nought and of obliterating in regard thereto the provisions contained in the Act relating to the imposition of tax on the sale or purchase of such goods and in particular the provisions contained in the charging section and the provisions contained in r. 20 (2) and other provisions which are incidental to the process of levying such tax.

anchor.surface_text: What, then, is the effect of this non-obstante provision ? This Court in Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose  1  made the following observations in connection with the non-obstante clause It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair construction of the words used according to their natural and ordinary meaning,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause overrides inconsistent prior provisions per Aswani Kumar Ghosh; applies to exclude Art.286-prohibited sales from Act's taxing machinery including turnover calculation.

holdings.text: Sales or purchases falling within categories specified in Art. 286 and corresponding s. 26 are taken out of the purview of the Act; no effect to otherwise applicable provisions.

anchor.surface_text: the non-obstante clause is to be understood as operating to set aside as no longer valid anything contained in relevant existing laws which is inconsistent with the new enactment. The same ratio applies to the construction of the non- obstante provision contained in s. 26 of the Act with reference to all the other provisions of the Act that preceded the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obliterates application of s.3 charging section and r.20 deduction for prohibited sales; follows non-obstante construction precedent.

holdings.text: Value of inter-State sales of oil cannot be included in dealer's turnover; no applicability of r.7(1)(k) and r.20(2) deductions for corresponding copra.

anchor.surface_text: If these provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder do not apply to. the sales falling within those categories, the value thereof cannot be included in the turnover of the dealer and no question would arise of the applicability of r. 7 (1) (k) and r. 20 (2) at all to these cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since s.26 removes from Act's purview, no inclusion in gross turnover, hence no r.20 deduction available for inter-state portion.

holdings.text: No distinction between inclusion of inter-State sales value in turnover for assessment purposes and levy of tax thereon; s.26 prohibits both by removing liability declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The amount for which the oil is sold in inter-State trade or commerce would not be lawfully included in the turnover of the dealer and no question would arise of the applicability of r. 7 (1) (k) and r. 20 (2) at all to these cases. A distinction was sought to be made between the inclusion of the value of such oil in the turnover of the dealer for the purpose of assessment and the levy of tax thereupon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three stages of tax (liability declaration first per Chatturam); no liability means no assessment or turnover inclusion.

holdings.text: Broad distinction exists: exemption/refund/rebate provisions require inclusion in gross turnover then deduction; non-liability/non-imposition excludes from turnover and Act's purview entirely; s.26 enacts non-liability.

anchor.surface_text: There is a broad distinction between the provisions contained in the statute in regard to the exemptions of tax or refund or rebate of tax on the one hand and in regard to the non-liability to tax or non-imposition of tax on the other. In the former case, but for the provisions as regards the exemptions or refund or rebate of tax, the sales or purchases would have to be included in the gross turnover of the dealer because they are prima facie liable to tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-liability transactions outside Act; no prima facie liability to trigger inclusion/deduction process.

holdings.text: Non-obstante provision in s.26 takes inter-State transactions out of Act's purview; dealer not required nor entitled to include them in taxable turnover calculations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect: strict fiscal construction + non-obstante override + no-liability distinction excludes inter-State sales/purchases entirely from turnover.

holdings.text: In construing fiscal statutes, regard must be had to strict letter of law, not spirit or substance; tax only if case falls strictly within provisions.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that in construing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and not merely to the spirit of the statute or the substance of the law. If the Revenue satisfies the Court that the case falls strictly within the provisions of the law, the subject can be taxed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms literal rule per Duke of Westminster, Partington, Bank of Chettinad; applies to interpret s.26 strictly excluding prohibited sales.

precedents.citation: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster 1

anchor.surface_text: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster 1  I -confess that I view with disfavour the doctrine that in taxation cases the subject is to be taxed if in accordance with a Courts view of what it companysiders the substance of the transaction, the Court thinks that the case falls within the companytemplation or spirit of the statute. The subject is number taxable by inference or by analogy, but only by the plain words of a statute applicable to the facts and circumstances of his case.

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v Duke of Westminster
precedents.cited_proposition: In taxation cases the subject is to be taxed upon the plain words of the statute and not by inference, analogy, or the spirit of the statute
precedents.cited_holding: I confess that I view with disfavour the doctrine that in taxation cases the subject is to be taxed if in accordance with a Court's view of what it considers the substance of the transaction, the Court thinks that the case falls within the contemplation or spirit of the statute

anchor.surface_text: Partington v. The Attorney General 1 -As I understand the  1  1936 A.C. 1, 24.  2  1869  4 H.L. 100, 122. principle of all fiscal legislation it is this if the person sought to be taxed companyes within the letter of the law he must be taxed, however great the hardship may appear to the judicial mind to be.

precedents.cited_proposition: If the person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law he must be taxed; if not, he is free however apparently within the spirit
precedents.cited_holding: As I understand the principle of all fiscal legislation it is this: If the person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law he must be taxed, however great the hardship may appear to the judicial mind to be. On the other hand, if the Crown... cannot bring the subject within the letter of the law the subject is free

precedents.citation: Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner 1

anchor.surface_text: Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner 1  and the Privy Council registered its protest against the suggestion that in revenue cases the substance of the matter may be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position.  See also F. L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood 2  .

precedents.case_name: Bank of Chettinad v Income Tax Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: In revenue cases the substance of the matter should not be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position

precedents.citation: F. L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood 2

anchor.surface_text: See also F. L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood 2  . It is numberdoubt true that in companystruing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and number merely to the spirit of the statute or the substance of the law.

precedents.case_name: F L Smidth Co v F Greenwood
precedents.cited_proposition: Strict letter of the law governs in fiscal statutes

precedents.citation: Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1  made the following observations in companynection with the number-obstante clause It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair companystruction of the words used according to their natural and ordinary meaning,

precedents.case_name: Aswani Kumar Ghosh v Arabinda Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: Construction of non-obstante clause: ascertain enacting part first, then non-obstante sets aside inconsistent prior law
precedents.cited_holding: It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair construction of the words used according to their natural and ordinary meaning, and the non-obstante clause is to be understood as operating to set aside as no longer valid anything contained in relevant existing laws which is inconsistent with the new enactment

precedents.citation: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar and Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this position on the observations of this Court in Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar and Orissa 1  As has been pointed out by the Federal Court in Chatturam C.I.T., Bihar ,   quoting from the

precedents.case_name: Chatturam Horilram Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Three stages in imposition of tax: declaration of liability, assessment, recovery
precedents.cited_holding: There are three stages in the imposition of a tax... declaration of liability... assessment... methods of recovery

anchor.surface_text: As has been pointed out by the Federal Court in Chatturam C.I.T., Bihar ,   quoting from the  1  1955 2 S.C.R. 290, 297.  2  1947 F.C.R. 116, 126. judgment of Lord Dunedin in Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1  there are three stages in the imposition of a tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: Three stages in imposition of tax: declaration of liability, assessment, recovery

precedents.citation: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1

anchor.surface_text: judgment of Lord Dunedin in Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1  there are three stages in the imposition of a tax. There is the declaration of liability, that is the part of the statute which determines what person in respect of what property are liable.

precedents.case_name: Whitney v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Three stages in the imposition of a tax: declaration of liability, assessment, recovery

anchor.surface_text: There is a broad distinction between the provisions contained in the statute in regard to the exemptions of tax or refund or rebate of tax on the one hand and in regard to the non-liability to tax or non-imposition of tax on the other.
